abstract: Long before four employees of the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week, people working in China’s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten.
snippet: Long before four employees of the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week, people working in China’s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten.
lead_paragraph: Long before four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto were detained in Shanghai last week on suspicion of stealing state secrets, people working in China’s steel industry were complaining about bribery, deceit and a system turned rotten, The New York Times’s David Barboza writes.

headline.main: Something’s Rotten in Chinese Steel Industry
